t: Job 21
Job Says God Will Deal with the Wicked
Then*p Job answered,
“Listen*pn carefully to my speech, And*ln let this be your way*i of*i consolation.
Bear*ln with me that I may speak; Then*ln after I have spoken, you may mock.
As*ln for me, is my complaint to man? And*ln why should I not be impatient?
Look*ln at me, and be astonished, And*ln put your*i hand over your*i mouth.
Even*ln when I remember, I am disturbed, And*ln horror takes hold of my flesh.
Why*ln do the wicked still*i live, Continue*ln on, also become very powerful?
Their*ln descendants are established with them in their sight, And*ln their offspring before their eyes,
Their*ln houses are safe from fear, And*ln the rod of God is not on them.
His*ln ox mates without fail; His*ln cow calves and does not abort.
They*ln send forth their little ones like the flock, And*ln their children skip about.
They*ln sing to the timbrel and harp And*ln rejoice at the sound of the flute.
They*ln spend their days in prosperity, And*ln suddenly they go down to Sheol.
They*ln say to God, ‘Depart from us! We*ln do not even desire the knowledge of Your ways.
Who*ln is the Almighty, that we should serve Him, And*ln what would we gain if we entreat Him?’
Behold,*ln their prosperity is not in their hand; The*ln counsel of the wicked is far from me.
“How*ln often is the lamp of the wicked put out, Or*ln does their calamity fall on them? Does*ln God apportion destruction in His anger?
Are*ln they as straw before the wind, And*ln like chaff which the storm carries away?
You*iln say,*i ‘God stores away a man’s iniquity for his sons.’ Let*ln God repay him so that he may know it.*i
Let*ln his own eyes see his decay, And*ln let him drink of the wrath of the Almighty.
For*ln what does he care for his household after him, When*ln the number of his months is cut off?
Can*ln anyone teach God knowledge, In*ln that He judges those on high?
One*ln dies in his full strength, Being*ln wholly at ease and satisfied;
His*ln sides are filled out with fat, And*ln the marrow of his bones is moist,
While*ln another dies with a bitter soul, Never*ln even tasting anything*i good.
Together*ln they lie down in the dust, And*ln worms cover them.
“Behold,*ln I know your thoughts, And*ln the plans by which you would wrong me.
For*ln you say, ‘Where is the house of the nobleman, And*ln where is the tent, the dwelling places of the wicked?’
Have*ln you not asked wayfaring men, And*ln do you not recognize their witness?
For*ln the wicked is reserved for the day of calamity; They*ln will be led forth at the day of fury.
Who*ln will confront him with his actions, And*ln who will repay him for what he has done?
While*ln he is carried to the grave, Men*iln will keep watch over his*i tomb.
The*ln clods of the valley will gently cover him; Moreover,*ln all men will follow after him, While*ln countless ones go*i before him.
How*ln then will you vainly comfort me, For*ln your answers remain full*i of*i falsehood?”
